column2: The Dao that can be spoken of is not the ever-constant Dao. (Chapter 1)
The name that can be named is not the ever-constant name. (Chapter 1)
That which is without-name is the beginning of heaven andearth. (Chapter 1)
That which possesses a name is the mother of the tenthousand creatures. (Chapter 1)
Therefore : always without-desire, thus you observe itssubtle mystery. (Chapter 1)
Always possessing desires, thus you observe its externalappearances. (Chapter 1)
These two, they arise from the same source but havedifferent names; (Chapter 1)
This sameness is called their deep mystery. (Chapter 1)
Deep mysteries, and again deep mysteries – (Chapter 1)
The gateway of many subtle mysteries. (Chapter 1)

column1: 天下皆知美之為美斯惡已
column2: In the world, when all know that the action of beauty isbeautiful, then ugliness ensues. (Chapter 2)

column1: 皆知善之為善斯不善已
column2: When all know that the action of good is goodness, thennot-good ensues. (Chapter 2)
Therefore : being and non-being create each other, (Chapter 2)
Difficult and easy complete each other, (Chapter 2)
Long and short contrast each other, (Chapter 2)
High and low lean on each other, (Chapter 2)
Tone and voice harmonize each other, (Chapter 2)
Before and after follow each other. (Chapter 2)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 2)
Lives by using non-action in his duties, (Chapter 2)
And practicing no-talking in his teachings. (Chapter 2)
The ten thousand creatures arise, but do not have abeginning. (Chapter 2)
Creating but not possessing; (Chapter 2)
Acting, but not concerned with the results; (Chapter 2)
Accomplishing tasks, but not dwelling on them. (Chapter 2)
Now : only because there is no dwelling, (Chapter 2)
Thus the results do not depart. (Chapter 2)
Not honoring those who are esteemable (Chapter 3)
Ensures that the citizens do not strive. (Chapter 3)
Not valuing rare goods (Chapter 3)
Ensures that the citizens do not act like thieves. (Chapter 3)
Not showing that which can be desired (Chapter 3)
Ensures that the citizens’ heart/minds do not becomeconfused. (Chapter 3)
Thus the governing of the sage (Chapter 3)
Empties their heart/minds, fills their stomachs, (Chapter 3)
Weakens their ambitions, strengthens their bones. (Chapter 3)
By always ensuring that the citizens arewithout-knowledge and without-desire, (Chapter 3)
Those who make men wise will not dare to act. (Chapter 3)
Act with non-action, then all will be governed! (Chapter 3)
Dao is like a cup or bowl, yet use it and there exists noneed to fill it. (Chapter 4)
Profound and deep!, it appears to be the ancestor of the tenthousand creatures. (Chapter 4)
It blunts their sharpness, (Chapter 4)
Loosens their tangles, (Chapter 4)
Softens their brightness, (Chapter 4)
Makes them the same as the dust of the world. (Chapter 4)
Deep and profound!, it seems to barely exist. (Chapter 4)
I do not know whose child it is – (Chapter 4)
Its image came before that of god. (Chapter 4)
Heaven and earth are not kind – (Chapter 5)
Thus the ten thousand creatures become as straw dogs tothem. (Chapter 5)
The sage is not kind – (Chapter 5)
Thus the 100 families become as straw dogs to him. (Chapter 5)
The space between heaven and earth, (Chapter 5)
How is it just like a bellows or flute? (Chapter 5)
It is empty, yet does not run out. (Chapter 5)
The more it moves, and the more it produces. (Chapter 5)
Too much talking is exceptionally exhausting, (Chapter 5)
Which is not as good as maintaining what is within. (Chapter 5)
The spirit of the valley does not die – (Chapter 6)
It is called the deep and mysterious feminine. (Chapter 6)
The gateway of this deep and mysterious feminine – (Chapter 6)
It is called the source of heaven and earth. (Chapter 6)
Unbroken, it seems to exist. (Chapter 6)
Using it takes no effort. (Chapter 6)
Heaven is eternal, earth is enduring. (Chapter 7)
The reason that heaven and earth can be eternal andenduring (Chapter 7)
Is because they do not live for themselves. (Chapter 7)
Therefore they can live forever. (Chapter 7)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 7)
Puts his self behind others, yet finds his self before them. (Chapter 7)
Considers his self extraneous, yet his self survives. (Chapter 7)
Is this not because he has no self-interests? (Chapter 7)
Therefore he can achieve his self-interests. (Chapter 7)
The highest virtue is like water – (Chapter 8)
Water’s virtue benefits the ten thousand creatures, yet itdoes not strive. (Chapter 8)
It dwells in places that everyone detests, (Chapter 8)
Therefore it is almost comparable to Dao! (Chapter 8)
In dwelling, the virtue is in the land. (Chapter 8)
In your heart/mind, the virtue is in being profound anddeep. (Chapter 8)
In relations, the virtue is in being kind. (Chapter 8)
In speech, the virtue is in being truthful. (Chapter 8)
In governing, the virtue is in being honest and just. (Chapter 8)
In your duties, the virtue is in being competent. (Chapter 8)
In action, the virtue is in the timing. (Chapter 8)
Now : only because there is no striving, (Chapter 8)
Therefore there is no blame. (Chapter 8)
Holding and filling it (Chapter 9)
Are not as good as your stopping short. (Chapter 9)
Hammering and sharpening it (Chapter 9)
Can not be forever maintained. (Chapter 9)
When gold and jade fill a room, (Chapter 9)
There is no one who can protect it. (Chapter 9)
To have wealth and high rank, but with arrogance – (Chapter 9)
Then naturally their loss is your own fault. (Chapter 9)
When the task is successful, the self should let go of it. (Chapter 9)
This is the Way of heaven. (Chapter 9)
Carrying and managing a body while embracing the One, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to not separate them? (Chapter 10)
Concentrating your Qi to become soft, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to be like a newborn infant? (Chapter 10)
Cleansing and clearing your deep and mysteriousperception, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to be without blemish? (Chapter 10)
Loving the citizens and governing the nation, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to use non-action? (Chapter 10)
Opening and closing the gateway of heaven, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to serve as the feminine? (Chapter 10)
Attaining clear insight in all directions, (Chapter 10)
Are you able to not use your knowledge? (Chapter 10)
Creating them and raising them, (Chapter 10)
Creating but not possessing, (Chapter 10)
Acting but not concerned with the results, (Chapter 10)
Leading yet not governing – (Chapter 10)
This is called deep and mysterious De. (Chapter 10)
Thirty spokes of a wheel share one hub; (Chapter 11)
In its emptiness exists the usefulness of the cart. (Chapter 11)
Mix water with clay thus making a vessel; (Chapter 11)
In its emptiness exists the usefulness of the vessel. (Chapter 11)
Cut out doors and windows thus making a room; (Chapter 11)
In their emptiness exists the usefulness of the room. (Chapter 11)
Therefore : what exists thus makes a thing profitable; (Chapter 11)
Emptiness thus makes it useful. (Chapter 11)
The five colors can make people’s eyes blind. (Chapter 12)
The five tones can make people’s ears deaf. (Chapter 12)
The five flavors can make people’s mouths dull. (Chapter 12)
Excessive hunting and horse racing can make people’sheart/minds become wild. (Chapter 12)
Rare goods can make people’s behavior corrupt. (Chapter 12)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 12)
Acts on what is inside, he does not act on what he sees. (Chapter 12)
Therefore he leaves that and chooses this. (Chapter 12)
Favor and disgrace seem alarming. (Chapter 13)
High rank brings great suffering if you have a self. (Chapter 13)
What is meant by “favor and disgrace seem alarming”? (Chapter 13)
Favor makes you the inferior, so gaining it seems alarming. (Chapter 13)
Losing it also seems alarming. (Chapter 13)
This is what is meant by “favor and disgrace seemalarming”. (Chapter 13)
What is meant by “high rank brings great suffering if youhave a self”? (Chapter 13)

column1: 吾所以有大患者為吾有身
column2: I am the reason that I have great suffering, I who act likeI have a self. (Chapter 13)
When I am without a self, how could I have suffering? (Chapter 13)
Therefore : he who is high ranking and uses his self toserve the world – (Chapter 13)
It seems he can thus be entrusted with the world! (Chapter 13)
He who is loving and uses his self to serve the world – (Chapter 13)
It seems he can thus be entrusted with the world! (Chapter 13)
Look, it is not seen; its name is called elusive. (Chapter 14)
Listen, it is not heard; its name is called tenuous. (Chapter 14)
Grasp, it is not gotten; its name is called subtle andobscure. (Chapter 14)
These three things can not be investigated any further – (Chapter 14)
Therefore they blend and become one. (Chapter 14)
This one thing : (Chapter 14)
Its highest point is not bright; (Chapter 14)
Its lowest point is not dark. (Chapter 14)
Continuous and unending!, it can not be named; (Chapter 14)
It returns to non-existence. (Chapter 14)
It is called the form of that which is without-form; (Chapter 14)
The image of non-existence. (Chapter 14)
It is called confusing and indistinct. (Chapter 14)
Meet it and you do not see its beginning; (Chapter 14)
Follow it and you do not see its end. (Chapter 14)
Hold fast to the Way of the ancients (Chapter 14)
In order to master the present moment. (Chapter 14)
The ability to know the ancient beginning – (Chapter 14)
This is called the main principle of Dao. (Chapter 14)

column1: 古之善為士者微妙玄通
column2: The virtue of the ancients made they who were scholarssubtle, mysterious, obscure, deep, and penetrating. (Chapter 15)
Their mysterious depths can not be understood. (Chapter 15)
Now : only because they can not be understood, (Chapter 15)
Therefore we try to emulate their appearance : (Chapter 15)
Hesitant!, as if crossing a winter stream. (Chapter 15)
Wary!, as if afraid of their neighbors all around. (Chapter 15)
Respectful!, they are like a visiting guest. (Chapter 15)
Yielding!, like ice that is about to to break off. (Chapter 15)
Honest and genuine!, they are like the uncarved block. (Chapter 15)
Wide and open!, they are like a valley. (Chapter 15)
Unclear!, they are like muddy water. (Chapter 15)
Who can take muddy water and use stillness to slowly andgently make it pure and clear? (Chapter 15)
Who can take what is tranquil and use continual movementto slowly and gently bring it to life? (Chapter 15)
He who maintains this Way does not desire to be full. (Chapter 15)
Now : only because he is not full, (Chapter 15)
Thus he can be hidden and unfinished. (Chapter 15)
Attain the utmost emptiness. (Chapter 16)
Maintain a profound stillness. (Chapter 16)
The ten thousand creatures arise in unison, (Chapter 16)
And thus I observe their return. (Chapter 16)
Now : all the myriad creatures return to their source. (Chapter 16)
Returning to the source speaks of stillness. (Chapter 16)
Stillness is called returning to the natural order. (Chapter 16)
Returning to the natural order speaks of the ever-constant. (Chapter 16)
Knowing the ever-constant speaks of insight. (Chapter 16)
Not knowing the ever-constant is foolish and createsmisfortune. (Chapter 16)
Knowing the ever-constant leads to tolerance. (Chapter 16)
Being tolerant leads to being just and unbiased. (Chapter 16)
Being just and unbiased leads to being kingly. (Chapter 16)
Being kingly leads to heaven. (Chapter 16)
Heaven leads to Dao. (Chapter 16)
Dao leads to what endures. (Chapter 16)
When the self disappears, there can be no danger. (Chapter 16)
The existence of the best ruler is barely known to thepeople. (Chapter 17)
Next is one who they love and praise. (Chapter 17)
Next is one who they fear. (Chapter 17)
Next is one who they ridicule. (Chapter 17)
If the ruler does not trust enough, then he will not haveanyone’s trust. (Chapter 17)
Thoughtful!, he values his words. (Chapter 17)
When tasks are accomplished and duties are successful, (Chapter 17)
The 100 families all say “we are naturally so”. (Chapter 17)
When the great Dao is abandoned, (Chapter 18)
There exists kindness and morality. (Chapter 18)
When intelligence and wisdom arise, (Chapter 18)
There exists a great deal of deception. (Chapter 18)
When the six relationships are not in harmony, (Chapter 18)
There exists devoted children and loving parents. (Chapter 18)
When the nation and the families are very confused, (Chapter 18)
There exists loyal officials. (Chapter 18)
Renounce sacredness, abandon wisdom, (Chapter 19)
And the citizens benefit 100-fold. (Chapter 19)
Renounce kindness, abandon morality, (Chapter 19)
And the citizens return to being devoted children andloving parents. (Chapter 19)
Renounce cleverness, abandon profit, (Chapter 19)
And thieves and bandits will not exist. (Chapter 19)
These three things thus make a civilized society, but are notenough. (Chapter 19)
Therefore : to ensure the citizens have a place to belong – (Chapter 19)
See the simplicity, (Chapter 19)
Embrace the concept of the uncarved block, (Chapter 19)
Less selfishness, (Chapter 19)
Fewer desires. (Chapter 19)
Renounce learning and be without worry. (Chapter 20)
“Yes” together with “yeah” – (Chapter 20)
What is their mutual distance or nearness? (Chapter 20)
Beautiful together with ugliness – (Chapter 20)
What is their mutual distance or similarity? (Chapter 20)
That which people fear, they are not able to not fear. (Chapter 20)
How ridiculous! They are not yet centered! (Chapter 20)
Everyone is very festive, (Chapter 20)
As if enjoying the Tai Lao sacrifice, (Chapter 20)
As if climbing terraces in the spring. (Chapter 20)
I alone am unmoved! – (Chapter 20)
Like one who has not yet given any sign, (Chapter 20)
Like a newborn infant who does not yet act like a baby. (Chapter 20)
Very tired and worn out!, as if without a place to return to. (Chapter 20)
Everyone all has more than they need; (Chapter 20)
I alone seem to have lost everything. (Chapter 20)
I have the heart/mind of a foolish person, indeed!! (Chapter 20)
I am very mixed up and confused! (Chapter 20)
Common people are very clear and bright; (Chapter 20)
I alone seem confused. (Chapter 20)
Common people are very observant and alert; (Chapter 20)
I alone am very gloomy and depressed. (Chapter 20)
Tranquil!, they are like the ocean; (Chapter 20)
I drift on the wind!, as if without a place to rest. (Chapter 20)
Everyone all has a purpose; (Chapter 20)
I alone am stupid and stubborn, and appear mean andshallow. (Chapter 20)
I alone am different compared to other people, (Chapter 20)
And value the food of the mother. (Chapter 20)
The greatest De is possible only when Dao is followed. (Chapter 21)
The action of Dao on creatures is just indistinct, justconfusing. (Chapter 21)
Confusing! and indistinct!, within it exists image. (Chapter 21)
Indistinct! and confusing!, within it exists things. (Chapter 21)
Obscure! and dark!, within it exists essence. (Chapter 21)
Its essence is extremely real and true. (Chapter 21)
Within it exists truth. (Chapter 21)
From the present, reaching to antiquity, (Chapter 21)
Its name has not departed – (Chapter 21)
Thus I observe the father of the multitudes. (Chapter 21)
How do I thus know the father of the multitudes is likethis? (Chapter 21)
By means of this. (Chapter 21)
What is wrong then becomes whole and perfect. (Chapter 22)
What is bent then becomes straight. (Chapter 22)
What is hollow then becomes filled. (Chapter 22)
What is worn out then becomes new. (Chapter 22)
Have little, then gain. (Chapter 22)
Have too much, then become confused. (Chapter 22)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 22)
Embraces the One, thus serving as an example to theworld – (Chapter 22)
He does not display himself, therefore he has insight. (Chapter 22)
Does not consider himself correct, therefore hedistinguishes himself. (Chapter 22)
Does not boast about himself, therefore he possessesmerit. (Chapter 22)
Does not brag about himself, therefore he endures. (Chapter 22)
Now : only because he does not strive, (Chapter 22)
Therefore no one in the world can strive against him. (Chapter 22)
That which the ancients say : (Chapter 22)
“He who is wrong then becomes whole and perfect” – (Chapter 22)
How can these be empty words? (Chapter 22)
Be truly whole and perfect, and return to it. (Chapter 22)
Minimal words are naturally so. (Chapter 23)
Therefore : strong winds do not last the entire morning, (Chapter 23)
Sudden rains do not last the entire day. (Chapter 23)
Who makes these things?  Heaven and earth. (Chapter 23)
Even heaven and earth can not maintain them forever, (Chapter 23)
And so how much less can people? (Chapter 23)
Therefore : of those who engage in Dao – (Chapter 23)
He who Daos is one with Dao. (Chapter 23)
He who Des is one with De. (Chapter 23)
He who loses is one with the loss. (Chapter 23)
For he who is one with Dao, (Chapter 23)
Dao is also pleased to have him. (Chapter 23)
For he who is one with De, (Chapter 23)
De is also pleased to have him. (Chapter 23)
For he who is one with loss, (Chapter 23)
Loss is also pleased to have him. (Chapter 23)
If you do not trust enough, then you will not have (Chapter 23)
He who stands on tiptoe does not really stand. (Chapter 24)
He who stands astride can not travel. (Chapter 24)
He who displays himself does not have insight. (Chapter 24)
He who considers himself correct does not distinguishhimself. (Chapter 24)
He who boasts about himself is without merit. (Chapter 24)
He who brags about himself does not endure. (Chapter 24)
He who lives in Dao – (Chapter 24)
Calls these leftover food and unnecessary behavior. (Chapter 24)
Creatures detest them, no matter what. (Chapter 24)
Therefore : he who possesses Dao does not live by them. (Chapter 24)
Something existed unformed yet complete, (Chapter 25)
Before heaven and earth were created. (Chapter 25)
Silent!  Empty! (Chapter 25)
Standing alone, not changing. (Chapter 25)
It circulates everywhere, and causes no danger. (Chapter 25)
It can be considered the mother of the world. (Chapter 25)
I do not know its name; (Chapter 25)
Its symbol is called Dao. (Chapter 25)
If I tried to make its name, I would call it great. (Chapter 25)
Being great speaks of departing. (Chapter 25)
Departing speaks of being remote. (Chapter 25)
Being remote speaks of returning. (Chapter 25)
Dao is great, (Chapter 25)
Heaven is great, (Chapter 25)
Earth is great, (Chapter 25)
The king is also great. (Chapter 25)
Within the realm exist four that are great, (Chapter 25)
And the king resides as one of them! (Chapter 25)
People follow the earth. (Chapter 25)
The earth follows heaven. (Chapter 25)
Heaven follows Dao. (Chapter 25)
Dao follows what is naturally so. (Chapter 25)
Serious serves as the source of frivolous. (Chapter 26)
Stillness serves as the ruler of restlessness. (Chapter 26)
Thus the noble man travels the entire day, (Chapter 26)
And does not stray from his wagon. (Chapter 26)
He is serious, even though glorious sights and feasts exist; (Chapter 26)
He lives above them, like this. (Chapter 26)
So how could one be the master of ten thousand chariots, (Chapter 26)
And conduct his self frivolously in the world? (Chapter 26)
Be frivolous, then lose the source. (Chapter 26)
Be restless, then lose the rulership. (Chapter 26)
A good traveler is without wagon track or footprint. (Chapter 27)
A good speaker is without flaw or disgrace. (Chapter 27)
A good accountant does not use counting tokens. (Chapter 27)
A good barrier is without bar or lock, yet can not beopened. (Chapter 27)
A good binding is without cord or restraint, yet can not beloosened. (Chapter 27)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 27)
Is always good at helping people, (Chapter 27)
Therefore he does not abandon people. (Chapter 27)
Is always good at helping creatures, (Chapter 27)
Therefore he does not abandon creatures. (Chapter 27)
This is called following your insight. (Chapter 27)
Therefore : he who is a virtuous person is the teacher of hewho is not a virtuous person. (Chapter 27)
He who is not a virtuous person is the resource of he whois a virtuous person. (Chapter 27)
If the latter does not value his teacher, (Chapter 27)
Or the former does not love his resource, (Chapter 27)
Even if there is wisdom, there will be great confusion. (Chapter 27)
This is called the essential subtle mystery. (Chapter 27)
Know your maleness, but maintain your femaleness. (Chapter 28)
Serve as a stream to the world. (Chapter 28)
Serving as a stream to the world, (Chapter 28)
The ever-constant De will not depart, (Chapter 28)
Returning you to the state of the newborn infant. (Chapter 28)
Know your brightness, but maintain your darkness. (Chapter 28)
Serve as an example to the world. (Chapter 28)
Serving as an example to the world, (Chapter 28)
The ever-constant De will not falter, (Chapter 28)
Returning you to the state of the limitless. (Chapter 28)
Know your honor, but maintain your disgrace. (Chapter 28)
Serve as a valley to the world. (Chapter 28)
Serving as a valley to the world, (Chapter 28)
The ever-constant De will then be sufficient, (Chapter 28)
Returning you to the state of the uncarved block. (Chapter 28)
When the uncarved block is broken up, then it becomestools. (Chapter 28)
When the sage uses it, then he becomes the seniorgovernment official. (Chapter 28)
Therefore : the greatest cutting does not divide. (Chapter 28)
Would you take hold of the world and control it? (Chapter 29)
I see you have no choice. (Chapter 29)
Now : the world is a divine vessel, (Chapter 29)
You can not control it (indeed!). (Chapter 29)
He who acts, ruins it; (Chapter 29)
He who grasps, loses it. (Chapter 29)
Therefore : creatures are (Chapter 29)
Sometimes active, sometimes passive, (Chapter 29)
Sometimes breathe heavy, sometimes breathe easy, (Chapter 29)
Sometimes strong, sometimes weak, (Chapter 29)
Sometimes oppressed, sometimes overthrown. (Chapter 29)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 29)
Removes the extremes, (Chapter 29)
Removes the extravagant and wasteful, (Chapter 29)
Removes the arrogance. (Chapter 29)
He who uses Dao to assist the master of the people (Chapter 30)
Does not use weapons or strength on the world, (Chapter 30)
For his troubles would likely return – (Chapter 30)
In the dwelling places of armies, thorns and brambles areproduced, (Chapter 30)
And so what is left behind a great army must have a badyear. (Chapter 30)
He who has virtue gets results and stops. (Chapter 30)
He does not dare to take by using strength. (Chapter 30)
He gets results, but never brags. (Chapter 30)
Gets results, but never boasts. (Chapter 30)
Gets results, but is not arrogant. (Chapter 30)
Gets results, but only when he has no choice. (Chapter 30)
Gets results, but never uses strength. (Chapter 30)
When creatures are robust but old, (Chapter 30)
This is called “not Dao”. (Chapter 30)
That which is “not Dao” has an early finish. (Chapter 30)
Now : fine weapons, they are not tools of good fortune. (Chapter 31)
Creatures detest them, no matter what. (Chapter 31)
Therefore : he who possesses Dao does not live by them. (Chapter 31)
When a noble man is in his dwelling, then he honors theleft. (Chapter 31)
When he commands troops, then he honors the right. (Chapter 31)
Weapons, they are not tools of good fortune. (Chapter 31)
They are not the tools of a noble man. (Chapter 31)
When he has no choice but to use them, (Chapter 31)
To be calm and indifferent is superior – (Chapter 31)
Never pleased, indeed! (Chapter 31)
And he who is pleased enjoys killing people. (Chapter 31)
Now : he who enjoys killing people (Chapter 31)
Can not get what he desires from the world! (Chapter 31)
Therefore : in fortunate affairs honor the left, (Chapter 31)
In unfortunate affairs honor the right. (Chapter 31)
Thus the assistant general of the army resides on the left, (Chapter 31)
The supreme general of the army resides on the right. (Chapter 31)
Thus we say they are dwelling at a funeral : (Chapter 31)
When many people are killed, (Chapter 31)
Then mourn and weep with grief for them. (Chapter 31)
Victory in war thus means they will dwell at a funeral. (Chapter 31)
Dao is ever-constantly without-name. (Chapter 32)
Even though the concept of the uncarved block seemsinsignificant, (Chapter 32)
No one in the world can conquer it. (Chapter 32)
If nobles and kings could maintain it, (Chapter 32)
The ten thousand creatures would naturally obey. (Chapter 32)
Heaven and earth would join with each other, (Chapter 32)
Thus dropping a sweet dew. (Chapter 32)
There are no citizens who would make this happen, (Chapter 32)
Yet it would be naturally fair and impartial. (Chapter 32)
And so, begin to divide and you have names. (Chapter 32)
Once names exist, (Chapter 32)
Men should also be ready to know when to stop. (Chapter 32)
Knowing when to stop is the reason that there is no danger. (Chapter 32)
An analogy for the action of Dao in the world : (Chapter 32)
It is similar to a stream in a valley that becomes part of a (Chapter 32)
He who knows people is wise; (Chapter 33)
He who knows himself has insight. (Chapter 33)
He who is victorious over people possesses power; (Chapter 33)
He who is victorious over himself is strong. (Chapter 33)
He who knows he has enough is wealthy; (Chapter 33)
He who uses force possesses ambition. (Chapter 33)
He who does not lose his place endures; (Chapter 33)
He who dies yet does not perish has longevity. (Chapter 33)
Great Dao is like a vast flood! (Chapter 34)
It is able to flow left and right. (Chapter 34)
The ten thousand creatures depend on it in order for life, (Chapter 34)
And are not rejected. (Chapter 34)
It accomplishes its tasks successfully, (Chapter 34)
Yet does not possess a name. (Chapter 34)
It clothes and supports the ten thousand creatures, (Chapter 34)
But does not act as their master. (Chapter 34)
Therefore : since it is ever-constantly without-desire, (Chapter 34)
It can then be named insignificant. (Chapter 34)
Since the ten thousand creatures return to it (Chapter 34)
But it does not act as their master, (Chapter 34)
It can then be named great. (Chapter 34)
Thus the sage can achieve greatness (Chapter 34)
Because he does not act great. (Chapter 34)
Therefore he can achieve greatness. (Chapter 34)
Holding fast to the great image, (Chapter 35)
The entire world comes towards you. (Chapter 35)
Comes towards you, and meeting with no harm, (Chapter 35)
There is the greatest peace and calm. (Chapter 35)
Music together with good food make passing guests stay, (Chapter 35)
But Dao’s words are bland! (Chapter 35)
They are without flavor. (Chapter 35)
Look for it, there is not enough to see. (Chapter 35)
Listen for it, there is not enough to hear. (Chapter 35)
Use it, there is not enough to exhaust. (Chapter 35)
When you are about to gather something, (Chapter 36)
You must have originally spread it out. (Chapter 36)
When you are about to weaken something, (Chapter 36)
You must have originally strengthened it. (Chapter 36)
When you are about to abandon something, (Chapter 36)
You must have originally been interested in it. (Chapter 36)
When you are about to seize something, (Chapter 36)
You must have originally given it. (Chapter 36)
This is called subtle and obscure insight. (Chapter 36)
What is soft and weak conquers what is hard and strong. (Chapter 36)
Fish can not escape from the deep; (Chapter 36)
The sharp tools of the nation (Chapter 36)
Can not be shown to the people. (Chapter 36)
Dao ever-constantly practices non-action, (Chapter 37)
Yet nothing is left undone. (Chapter 37)
If nobles and kings could maintain it, (Chapter 37)
The ten thousand creatures would naturally transform. (Chapter 37)
Transform, and if desire arises, (Chapter 37)
I would restrain it by means of the nameless uncarvedblock. (Chapter 37)
In the state of the nameless uncarved block, (Chapter 37)
Men also would be without-desire. (Chapter 37)
Not desiring, thus they would be still – (Chapter 37)
And the world would naturally settle. (Chapter 37)
A man of highest De does not use his De, thus hepossesses De. (Chapter 38)
A man of inferior De does not lose his De, thus he iswithout De. (Chapter 38)
A man of highest De uses non-action, and acts withoutmotive. (Chapter 38)
A man of inferior De coerces others, and has a motive toact. (Chapter 38)
A man of highest kindness coerces others, and actswithout motive. (Chapter 38)
A man of highest morality coerces others, and has amotive to act. (Chapter 38)
A man of highest propriety coerces others, and if thereis no one who responds, (Chapter 38)
Then he rolls up his sleeves and keeps doing it. (Chapter 38)
Therefore : lose Dao, and later comes De. (Chapter 38)
Lose De, and later comes kindness. (Chapter 38)
Lose kindness, and later comes morality. (Chapter 38)
Lose morality, and later comes propriety. (Chapter 38)
Now : propriety is that which is merely the appearance ofloyalty and honesty, (Chapter 38)
And the beginning of confusion. (Chapter 38)
He who is ahead in knowledge has the flower of Dao, (Chapter 38)
But the beginning of stupidity and foolishness. (Chapter 38)
Thus the greatest elders : (Chapter 38)
Live by Dao’s substance, and do not dwell on Dao’sappearance. (Chapter 38)
Live on Dao’s fruit, and do not dwell on Dao’s flower. (Chapter 38)
Therefore they leave that and choose this. (Chapter 38)
Of those who in ancient times attained oneness : (Chapter 39)
Heaven attained oneness, thus becoming pure and clear. (Chapter 39)
Earth attained oneness, thus becoming stable. (Chapter 39)
Spirit attained oneness, thus becoming potent. (Chapter 39)
The valley attained oneness, thus becoming full. (Chapter 39)
The ten thousand creatures attained oneness, thusbecoming alive. (Chapter 39)
Nobles and kings attained oneness, thus serving the worldfaithfully. (Chapter 39)
They attained it. (Chapter 39)
If heaven could not use its purity and clarity, (Chapter 39)
I fear it would split apart. (Chapter 39)
If earth could not use its stability, (Chapter 39)
I fear it would erupt. (Chapter 39)
If spirit could not use its potency, (Chapter 39)
I fear it would cease to be. (Chapter 39)
If the valley could not use its fullness, (Chapter 39)
I fear it would be used up. (Chapter 39)
If the ten thousand creatures could not use their life, (Chapter 39)
I fear they would be destroyed. (Chapter 39)
If nobles and kings could not use their high rank andprominence, (Chapter 39)
I fear they would fall. (Chapter 39)
Therefore : humility thus serves as the source of high rank; (Chapter 39)
Low thus serves as the foundation of high. (Chapter 39)

column1: 是以侯王自謂孤寡不穀
column2: Thus nobles and kings call themselves orphaned, lonely,and unlucky. (Chapter 39)
Does this not mean that humility thus serves as the source? (Chapter 39)
Does it not? (Chapter 39)
Therefore : to attain exceptional popularity is to be withoutpopularity – (Chapter 39)
Do not desire to be scarce like jade, (Chapter 39)
But common like rock. (Chapter 39)
The movement of Dao returns things. (Chapter 40)
The function of Dao is to weaken things. (Chapter 40)
The ten thousand creatures of the world are created frombeing; (Chapter 40)
Being is created from non-being. (Chapter 40)
The superior scholar hearing of Dao works hard andpractices it. (Chapter 41)
The average scholar hearing of Dao seems to keep it,seems to lose it. (Chapter 41)
The inferior scholar hearing of Dao laughs greatly at it. (Chapter 41)
If he did not laugh, it would not be qualified to be Dao. (Chapter 41)
Therefore : in the established sayings that exist, it is said – (Chapter 41)
Insight into Dao seems like darkness. (Chapter 41)
Advancing in Dao seems like retreating. (Chapter 41)
Smooth Dao seems knotted. (Chapter 41)
Superior De seems like a valley. (Chapter 41)
The greatest purity seems like disgrace. (Chapter 41)
The most extensive De seems like it is not enough. (Chapter 41)
Established De seems aimless. (Chapter 41)
Real and true character seems inconsistent. (Chapter 41)
The greatest region is without borders. (Chapter 41)
The greatest vessel is last to be completed. (Chapter 41)
The greatest tone is a tenuous sound. (Chapter 41)
The greatest image is without-form. (Chapter 41)
Dao is hidden and without-name. (Chapter 41)
Now : only Dao is good at beginning and also good at (Chapter 41)
Dao creates one. (Chapter 42)
One creates two. (Chapter 42)
Two creates three. (Chapter 42)
Three creates the ten thousand creatures. (Chapter 42)
The ten thousand creatures carry Yin and embrace Yang, (Chapter 42)
Pouring their Qi together, thus becoming harmonious. (Chapter 42)
That which people detest : (Chapter 42)
Being alone, orphaned, lonely, and unlucky – (Chapter 42)
Yet kings and nobles thus name themselves. (Chapter 42)
Therefore : creatures (Chapter 42)
Sometimes lose, yet they gain; (Chapter 42)
Sometimes gain, yet they lose. (Chapter 42)
That which people teach, I also teach : (Chapter 42)
Those who are bullies and hoodlums do not meet theirnatural death. (Chapter 42)
I will thus become their elder teacher. (Chapter 42)
The softest things of the world (Chapter 43)
Overrun the hardest things of the world. (Chapter 43)
Non-being can enter where there is no space in between. (Chapter 43)
Thus I know that non-action has benefits. (Chapter 43)
The teaching of no-talking, (Chapter 43)
The benefit of non-action – (Chapter 43)
Few in the world attain these. (Chapter 43)
Fame and self : which do you love? (Chapter 44)
Self and property : which is greater? (Chapter 44)
Gain and loss : which is the affliction? (Chapter 44)
Extreme desire must lead to great expense. (Chapter 44)
Collecting too much must lead to substantial loss. (Chapter 44)
Knowing when you have enough, there can be no disgrace. (Chapter 44)
Knowing when to stop, there can be no danger. (Chapter 44)
Then you can forever endure. (Chapter 44)
Great achievement seems incomplete, (Chapter 45)
But its usefulness is not impaired. (Chapter 45)
Great fullness is like a cup or bowl, (Chapter 45)
Its usefulness is not exhausted. (Chapter 45)
Great straightness seems bent. (Chapter 45)
Great skillfulness seems clumsy. (Chapter 45)
Great debaters seem slow of speech. (Chapter 45)
Restlessness conquers cold. (Chapter 45)
Stillness conquers heat. (Chapter 45)
Purity and clarity along with stillness makes the world (Chapter 45)
When the world possesses Dao, (Chapter 46)
Riding horses are nonetheless used for manure. (Chapter 46)
When the world is without Dao, (Chapter 46)
War-horses are bred in the countryside. (Chapter 46)
There is no fault greater than the capacity for desire. (Chapter 46)
There is no misfortune greater than not knowing whenyou have enough. (Chapter 46)
There is no error greater than desire for gain. (Chapter 46)
Therefore : knowing the sufficiency of having enough, (Chapter 46)
You do not have to go out the door (Chapter 47)
In order to to know the world. (Chapter 47)
You do not have to look out the window (Chapter 47)
In order to to know the Way of heaven. (Chapter 47)
The farther you go out, (Chapter 47)
You know even less. (Chapter 47)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 47)
Does not travel, yet knows. (Chapter 47)
Does not display himself, yet has a reputation. (Chapter 47)
Does not act, yet accomplishes. (Chapter 47)
The actions of those who learn daily increase. (Chapter 48)
The actions of those who Dao daily decrease. (Chapter 48)
Decreasing and again decreasing, (Chapter 48)
In order to arrive at non-action. (Chapter 48)
Use non-action, and nothing is left undone. (Chapter 48)
To take hold of the world, always use non-interference. (Chapter 48)
When you are compelled  to interfere, (Chapter 48)
Then you are not qualified to take hold of the world. (Chapter 48)
The sage does not have a constant heart/mind, (Chapter 49)
Thus the 100 families’ heart/minds become his heart/mind. (Chapter 49)
He who is virtuous, I am virtuous to him. (Chapter 49)
He who is not virtuous, I am also virtuous to him. (Chapter 49)
Because De is virtue. (Chapter 49)
He who is honest, I am honest with him. (Chapter 49)
He who is not honest, I am also honest with him. (Chapter 49)
Because De is honesty. (Chapter 49)
The sage lives in the world, gathering it all in. (Chapter 49)
And so he serves the world, merging with theirheart/minds. (Chapter 49)
The 100 families all pay attention to their ears and eyes, (Chapter 49)
And the sage treats them all like his children. (Chapter 49)
Between coming out into life and entering death, (Chapter 50)
Followers of life are 3 in 10. (Chapter 50)
Followers of death are 3 in 10. (Chapter 50)
People whose lives are merely moving them towards theplace of death (Chapter 50)
Are also 3 in 10. (Chapter 50)
Now : what is the reason? (Chapter 50)
Because they live life for its substance. (Chapter 50)
But I have heard that he who is skilled at taking in life (Chapter 50)
Can travel the mountains and does not meet rhino or tiger, (Chapter 50)
Can enter a battle not wearing armor or weapons. (Chapter 50)
The rhino has no place to thrust its horns, (Chapter 50)
The tiger has no place to use its claws, (Chapter 50)
The weapon has no place to allow its blade. (Chapter 50)
Now : what is the reason? (Chapter 50)
Because for him there is no place of death. (Chapter 50)
Dao creates them, (Chapter 51)
De raises them, (Chapter 51)
Things shape them, (Chapter 51)
Circumstances complete them. (Chapter 51)
Thus among the ten thousand creatures, (Chapter 51)
There are none who do not respect Dao and honor De. (Chapter 51)
Respect of Dao, (Chapter 51)
Honor of De – (Chapter 51)
Now : there is no one who commands this, (Chapter 51)
Yet it is always naturally so. (Chapter 51)
Therefore : Dao creates them, De raises them. (Chapter 51)
Leads them, nourishes them, (Chapter 51)
Shelters them, heals  them, (Chapter 51)
Supports them, protects them. (Chapter 51)
Creating but not possessing, (Chapter 51)
Acting but not concerned with the results, (Chapter 51)
Leading yet not governing – (Chapter 51)
This is called deep and mysterious De. (Chapter 51)
The world had a beginning, (Chapter 52)
Which can be considered the mother of the world. (Chapter 52)
Once you have realized its mother, (Chapter 52)
You thus know her children. (Chapter 52)
Once you know her children, (Chapter 52)
Return to and maintain their mother. (Chapter 52)
When the self disappears, there can be no danger. (Chapter 52)
Block your senses, close your gateway – (Chapter 52)
All your life you will not struggle. (Chapter 52)
Open your senses, be successful in your duties – (Chapter 52)
All your life you will not have relief. (Chapter 52)
Seeing the insignificant speaks of insight. (Chapter 52)
Maintaining softness speaks of strength. (Chapter 52)
Use your brightness to return to your insight. (Chapter 52)
Do not lose your self in misfortune. (Chapter 52)
This is called practicing the ever-constant. (Chapter 52)
If I correctly use the tiniest bit of knowledge that I possess (Chapter 53)
While travelling on the great Way, (Chapter 53)
It is only walking off the path that I need to fear. (Chapter 53)
The great Way is extremely even, (Chapter 53)
But the citizens are fond of side paths. (Chapter 53)
Although the royal court is very well-kept, (Chapter 53)
The fields are very overgrown with weeds, (Chapter 53)
The granaries are very empty. (Chapter 53)
While at the court they wear refined multicolored silks, (Chapter 53)
Carry sharp swords, (Chapter 53)
Stuff themselves with drink and food, (Chapter 53)
And have an excess of wealth and goods. (Chapter 53)
This is called robbery and extravagance, (Chapter 53)
Not Dao, indeed!! (Chapter 53)
That which is well established is not uprooted. (Chapter 54)
That which is well embraced is not abandoned. (Chapter 54)
Thus children and grandchildren offer sacrifices, and sosacrifices do not stop. (Chapter 54)
Cultivate it in the self – your De will then be true and real. (Chapter 54)
Cultivate it in the family – its De will then be more thanenough. (Chapter 54)
Cultivate it in the village – its De will then last forever. (Chapter 54)
Cultivate it in the nation – its De will then be abundant. (Chapter 54)
Cultivate it in the world – its De will then be everywhere. (Chapter 54)
Therefore : use your self to contemplate the self. (Chapter 54)
Use your family to contemplate the family. (Chapter 54)
Use your village to contemplate the village. (Chapter 54)
Use your nation to contemplate the nation. (Chapter 54)
Use the world to contemplate the world. (Chapter 54)
How do I thus know the world is like this? (Chapter 54)
By means of this. (Chapter 54)
He who embodies the substance of De (Chapter 55)
Can be compared to a newborn child : (Chapter 55)
Wasps, scorpions, snakes, and serpents do not sting him, (Chapter 55)
Fierce beasts do not seize him, (Chapter 55)
Birds of prey do not claw him. (Chapter 55)
His bones are weak, his muscles are soft, yet his grasp isfirm and strong. (Chapter 55)
He has not yet known the union of female and male, yet hispenis rises. (Chapter 55)
He has the utmost essence, indeed! (Chapter 55)
He cries the entire day yet does not get hoarse. (Chapter 55)
He has the utmost harmony, indeed! (Chapter 55)
Knowing harmony speaks of the ever-constant. (Chapter 55)
Knowing the ever-constant speaks of insight. (Chapter 55)
Benefitting life speaks of good fortune. (Chapter 55)
Heart/mind making Qi speaks of strength. (Chapter 55)
When creatures are robust but old, (Chapter 55)
We call them “not Dao”. (Chapter 55)
That which is “not Dao” has an early finish. (Chapter 55)
He who knows does not speak; (Chapter 56)
He who speaks does not know. (Chapter 56)
Block your senses, close your gateway. (Chapter 56)
Blunt your sharpness, (Chapter 56)
Loosen your tangles, (Chapter 56)
Soften your brightness, (Chapter 56)
Be the same as the dust of the world. (Chapter 56)
This is called a deep and mysterious sameness. (Chapter 56)
Therefore : you can not gain it and be friendly, (Chapter 56)
Can not gain it and be unfriendly, (Chapter 56)
Can not gain it and benefit, (Chapter 56)
Can not gain it and cause harm, (Chapter 56)
Can not gain it and have high rank, (Chapter 56)
Can not gain it and be lowly. (Chapter 56)
Therefore you become valuable to the world. (Chapter 56)
Use honesty and justness when governing a nation. (Chapter 57)
Use strange and unusual tactics when commanding troops. (Chapter 57)
Use non-interference to take hold of the world. (Chapter 57)
How do I thus know it is like this? (Chapter 57)
By means of this : (Chapter 57)
The world has many prohibitions and taboos, (Chapter 57)
And the citizens become even poorer. (Chapter 57)
The citizens have many sharp tools, (Chapter 57)
And the nation and the families grow in confusion. (Chapter 57)
The people have too much knowledge and cleverness, (Chapter 57)
And strange things begin to increase. (Chapter 57)
Matters of law are increasingly proclaimed, (Chapter 57)
And more thieves and bandits exist. (Chapter 57)
Therefore : the sage says – (Chapter 57)
I use non-action, and the citizens naturally transform. (Chapter 57)
I cherish stillness, and the citizens naturally becomehonest and just. (Chapter 57)
I use non-interference, and the citizens naturally becomewealthy. (Chapter 57)
I am without-desire, and the citizens naturally return to the (Chapter 57)
If their government is very restrained, (Chapter 58)
Its citizens will be very genuine and honest. (Chapter 58)
If their government is very observant and alert, (Chapter 58)
Its citizens will be very lacking and deficient. (Chapter 58)
Misfortune! is that which good fortune leans on. (Chapter 58)
Good fortune! is that which misfortune lies on. (Chapter 58)
Who knows their limits? (Chapter 58)
They are not honest and just. (Chapter 58)
Honesty and justness returns, becoming strange andunusual. (Chapter 58)
Virtue returns, becoming weird and strange. (Chapter 58)
The confusion of the people – (Chapter 58)
Its days have indeed been everlasting. (Chapter 58)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 58)
Is honest and does not divide, (Chapter 58)
Is honorable and does not injure, (Chapter 58)
Is straightforward and does not indulge in excess, (Chapter 58)
Is bright but does not dazzle. (Chapter 58)
When governing people or doing heaven’s duties, (Chapter 59)
It is better to be sparing. (Chapter 59)
Now : only when you can be sparing, (Chapter 59)
This is called early acceptance. (Chapter 59)
Early acceptance is called doubling your accumulation ofDe. (Chapter 59)
With a double accumulation of De, (Chapter 59)
Then everything can be overcome. (Chapter 59)
When everything can be overcome, (Chapter 59)
Then no one knows your limits. (Chapter 59)
When no one knows your limits, (Chapter 59)
You can possess the nation. (Chapter 59)
Possessing the mother of the nation, (Chapter 59)
You can forever endure. (Chapter 59)
This is called having a deep source and a firm foundation, (Chapter 59)
The Way of long life and enduring sight. (Chapter 59)
Governing a great nation is like cooking a small fish. (Chapter 60)
Because Dao is present in the world, (Chapter 60)
Its ghosts do not have spirit. (Chapter 60)
Not that its ghosts do not have any spirit, (Chapter 60)
But their spirit does not injure people. (Chapter 60)
Not only does their spirit not injure people, (Chapter 60)
The sage also does not injure people. (Chapter 60)
Now : since these two do not injure each other, (Chapter 60)
Therefore their De merges and returns! (Chapter 60)
A great nation is like the lowest places water can flow – (Chapter 61)
The merging place of the world, (Chapter 61)
The female of the world. (Chapter 61)
The female always uses stillness to conquer the male. (Chapter 61)
By using stillness, she becomes lower-than. (Chapter 61)
Therefore : if a great nation is lower-than a small nation, (Chapter 61)
Then it takes hold of the small nation. (Chapter 61)
If a small nation is lower-than a great nation, (Chapter 61)
Then it is taken hold of by the great nation. (Chapter 61)
Therefore : sometimes one nation is lower-than in orderto take hold of, (Chapter 61)
Sometimes one nation is lower-than and then it is takenhold of. (Chapter 61)
A great nation merely desires to combine livestock andpeople, (Chapter 61)
A small nation merely desires to get work for its people. (Chapter 61)
Now : for both nations to each get that which is their desire, (Chapter 61)
It is proper for the great nation to be lower-than. (Chapter 61)
That which Daos is the obscure mystery of the ten thousand       creatures. (Chapter 62)
This is the treasure of a virtuous person, (Chapter 62)
And that which is the protection of a person who is notvirtuous. (Chapter 62)
Beautiful speech can be used in the market, (Chapter 62)
Respectful behavior can benefit people. (Chapter 62)
People who are not virtuous, (Chapter 62)
Why abandon them? (Chapter 62)
Therefore : when inaugurating the son of heaven, (Chapter 62)
Or installing the three nobles – (Chapter 62)
Even if you possessed jade disks drawn by a team of fourhorses, (Chapter 62)
That is not as good as sitting and offering this Way. (Chapter 62)
What was the ancients’ reason that they valued this Way? (Chapter 62)
Did they not say : (Chapter 62)
Seek in order to obtain, (Chapter 62)
Have faults in order to be forgiven? (Chapter 62)
Therefore Dao becomes valuable to the world. (Chapter 62)
Act with non-action. (Chapter 63)
Handle duties with non-interference. (Chapter 63)
Taste that which is without-flavor. (Chapter 63)
Greatness is insignificant, too much is less. (Chapter 63)
Repay animosity with De. (Chapter 63)
Plan for the difficult while it is easy. (Chapter 63)
Act on the great while it is tiny. (Chapter 63)
In the world, difficult duties certainly start while easy. (Chapter 63)
In the world, great duties certainly start while tiny. (Chapter 63)
Thus the sage in the end does not act great, (Chapter 63)
Therefore he can achieve his greatness. (Chapter 63)
Men who make promises lightly, certainly few will trust. (Chapter 63)
Men who expect most duties to be easy will certainly havemany difficulties. (Chapter 63)
Thus the sage plans for things to be difficult, (Chapter 63)
Therefore in the end he is without difficulty! (Chapter 63)
What is peaceful is easy to hold. (Chapter 64)
What has not yet been revealed is easy to plan for. (Chapter 64)
What is brittle is easy to shatter. (Chapter 64)
What is minute is easy to scatter. (Chapter 64)
Act on it while it does not yet exist. (Chapter 64)
Govern them while they are not yet confused. (Chapter 64)
A tree too big to embrace is created from the tiniest shoot. (Chapter 64)
A terrace of nine stories rises from a pile of dirt. (Chapter 64)
A journey of a thousand miles begins from under the feet. (Chapter 64)
He who acts, ruins it. (Chapter 64)
He who grasps, loses it. (Chapter 64)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 64)
Does not act, therefore he does not ruin. (Chapter 64)
Does not grasp, therefore he does not lose. (Chapter 64)

column1: 民之從事常於幾成而敗之
column2: Citizens are always on the verge of achieving theirundertakings, yet they ruin them. (Chapter 64)
Be as careful in the end as if it was the beginning, (Chapter 64)
Then you will not ruin your affairs. (Chapter 64)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 64)
Desires to not desire, (Chapter 64)
Does not value rare goods, (Chapter 64)
Learns to not learn. (Chapter 64)
He returns to that which everyone else has passed over, (Chapter 64)
Thus helping the ten thousand creatures to be naturally so, (Chapter 64)
Yet not daring to act. (Chapter 64)
The virtue of the ancients (they who acted in Dao), (Chapter 65)
Did not use it to enlighten the citizens, (Chapter 65)
But would have used it to keep them ignorant – (Chapter 65)
The citizens are hard to govern (Chapter 65)
Because they have too much knowledge. (Chapter 65)
Therefore : using knowledge to govern the nation (Chapter 65)
Is the bane of the nation. (Chapter 65)
Not using knowledge to govern the nation (Chapter 65)
Is the good fortune of the nation. (Chapter 65)
He who has knowledge of these two also has them asexamples. (Chapter 65)
To always understand these examples – (Chapter 65)
This is called deep and mysterious De. (Chapter 65)
Deep and mysterious De is so profound! and remote! (Chapter 65)
That when creatures return, it returns with them! (Chapter 65)
Then they reach the greatest harmony. (Chapter 65)

column1: 江海所以能為百谷王者
column2: The reason that rivers and seas can act as kings of the 100valleys (Chapter 66)
Is because they are good at being lower-than them. (Chapter 66)
Therefore : they can act as kings of the 100 valleys. (Chapter 66)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 66)
In desiring to be above the citizens, (Chapter 66)
He must by means of his speech be lower-than them. (Chapter 66)
In desiring to be before the citizens, (Chapter 66)
He must by means of his self be behind them. (Chapter 66)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 66)
Lives above them, but the citizens are not burdened. (Chapter 66)
Lives in front of them, but the citizens are not harmed. (Chapter 66)
Thus the world is pleased to promote him, and does nottire of him. (Chapter 66)
Because he does not strive, (Chapter 66)
Therefore no one in the world can strive against him. (Chapter 66)
In the world, all say I am great, (Chapter 67)
But do not seem to be like everyone else. (Chapter 67)
Now : only because I am not like everyone else, therefore Ican be great. (Chapter 67)
If I was like everyone else, (Chapter 67)
Long ago! I would have become insignificant, indeed! (Chapter 67)
Now : I possess three treasures – (Chapter 67)
Hold and maintain them. (Chapter 67)
The first is called compassion, (Chapter 67)
The second is called economy, (Chapter 67)
The third is called not daring to act first in the world. (Chapter 67)
With compassion, you can therefore be brave. (Chapter 67)
With economy, you can therefore expand. (Chapter 67)
By not daring to act first in the world, (Chapter 67)
Therefore you can achieve the capacity for leadership. (Chapter 67)
At present, people abandon compassion but also try to bebrave, (Chapter 67)
Abandon economy but also try to expand, (Chapter 67)
Abandon being behind but also try to be first – (Chapter 67)
This is death! (Chapter 67)
Now : when compassion is used in war, the consequenceis victory. (Chapter 67)
When it is used for protection, the consequence is strength. (Chapter 67)
When heaven would help you, (Chapter 67)
Using compassion it protects you. (Chapter 67)
He who is good at being a scholar is not militant. (Chapter 68)
He who is good at war does not get angry. (Chapter 68)
He who is good at conquering the enemy does not engagethem. (Chapter 68)
He who is good at making use of people acts lower-thanthem. (Chapter 68)
This is called the De of not striving. (Chapter 68)
This is called the power of making use of people. (Chapter 68)
This is called joining the elite of heaven’s ancients, indeed! (Chapter 68)
Those who command troops have a saying : (Chapter 69)
I dare not act like the master, but instead act like a guest. (Chapter 69)
Dare not advance an inch, but instead retreat a foot. (Chapter 69)
This is called marching without marching, (Chapter 69)
Seizing without using your arms, (Chapter 69)
Routing without having an enemy, (Chapter 69)
Defending without using weapons. (Chapter 69)
There is no misfortune greater than underestimating theenemy. (Chapter 69)
By underestimating the enemy, I nearly lose my treasures. (Chapter 69)
Therefore : when armies on opposing sides are evenlymatched, (Chapter 69)
Then they who mourn will be victorious! (Chapter 69)
My words are very easy to understand, (Chapter 70)
Very easy to practice. (Chapter 70)
But there is no one in the world who can understand them, (Chapter 70)
There is no one who can practice them. (Chapter 70)
My words possess a lineage, (Chapter 70)
My duties possess a ruler. (Chapter 70)
Now : only because I am without-knowledge, (Chapter 70)
Thus I am not understood. (Chapter 70)
Those who understand me are rare, (Chapter 70)
Consequently I am one who is valued! (Chapter 70)
Thus the sage wears coarse cloth, but carries jade in hisheart. (Chapter 70)
♦My words are very easy to understand, (Chapter 70)
Knowing that you do not know is honorable! (Chapter 71)
Not knowing that you know is a sickness! (Chapter 71)
Now : only when you are sick of sickness, (Chapter 71)
Thus you are not sick. (Chapter 71)
The sage is not sick (Chapter 71)
Because he is sick of sickness. (Chapter 71)
Thus he is not sick. (Chapter 71)
If the citizens do not fear your authority, (Chapter 72)
Then a greater authority will arrive! (Chapter 72)
Do not disrespect their dwellings, (Chapter 72)
Do not despise their livelihood. (Chapter 72)
Now : only because you do not despise them, (Chapter 72)
Thus they will not tire of you. (Chapter 72)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 72)
Knows himself but not display himself, (Chapter 72)
Loves himself but does not exalt himself. (Chapter 72)
Therefore he leaves that and chooses this. (Chapter 72)
When your courage lies in daring, (Chapter 73)
The consequence is killing. (Chapter 73)
When your courage lies in not daring, (Chapter 73)
The consequence is survival. (Chapter 73)
These two choices, they sometimes cause benefit,sometimes cause harm. (Chapter 73)
That which heaven detests – who knows its reasons? (Chapter 73)
The Way of heaven : (Chapter 73)
Does not strive, yet skillfully achieves its goals. (Chapter 73)
Does not speak, yet skillfully responds. (Chapter 73)
Does not summon, yet everything naturally comes to it. (Chapter 73)
Is certainly unhurried, yet skillfully prepares. (Chapter 73)
Heaven’s net is extremely vast; (Chapter 73)
It is wide meshed, yet does not fail. (Chapter 73)
♦When your courage* lies in daring, (Chapter 73)
If the citizens do not fear death, (Chapter 74)
How can you use death to frighten them? (Chapter 74)
Assuming you could ensure that the citizens always feardeath, (Chapter 74)

column1: 而為奇者吾得執而殺之
column2: And I get hold of those who act strange and unusual andkill them, (Chapter 74)
Then who would be daring? (Chapter 74)
There will always exist an executioner. (Chapter 74)
Now : to take the place of the executioner to do thekilling, (Chapter 74)
This is called taking the place of a great craftsman to carvewood. (Chapter 74)
Now : of those who take the place of a great craftsman tocarve wood, (Chapter 74)
Few will not injure their hand! (Chapter 74)
The citizens are hungry (Chapter 75)
Because their superiors eat too much of their taxes. (Chapter 75)
Thus they are hungry. (Chapter 75)
The citizens are hard to govern (Chapter 75)
Because their superiors are compelled to take action. (Chapter 75)
Thus they are hard to govern. (Chapter 75)
The citizens take death lightly (Chapter 75)
Because they seek the substance of life. (Chapter 75)
Thus they take death lightly. (Chapter 75)
Now : only he who has no use for being alive (Chapter 75)
Is virtuous compared to he who values living. (Chapter 75)
The people are born (indeed!) soft and weak. (Chapter 76)
They die (indeed!) hard and inflexible. (Chapter 76)
The ten thousand creatures, the grass and trees, are born(indeed!) soft and fragile. (Chapter 76)
They die (indeed!) dried and withered. (Chapter 76)
Therefore : that which is hard and inflexible is a followerof death. (Chapter 76)
That which is soft and weak is a follower of life. (Chapter 76)
Thus if a weapon is inflexible, the consequence is defeat. (Chapter 76)
If a tree is inflexible, then it snaps. (Chapter 76)
Inflexible and great dwell below. (Chapter 76)
Soft and weak dwell above. (Chapter 76)
The Way of heaven, how it is just like stretching a bow? (Chapter 77)
He who is high is pressed down by it. (Chapter 77)
He who is low is lifted by it. (Chapter 77)
He who has excess is reduced by it. (Chapter 77)
He who does not have enough is filled by it. (Chapter 77)
The Way of heaven (Chapter 77)
Reduces what has excess and fills what does not haveenough. (Chapter 77)
The Way of people on the other hand is not like this, (Chapter 77)
And takes from those who do not have enough in order tooffer it to those who have too much. (Chapter 77)
Who can have too much and offer it to the world? (Chapter 77)
Only he who possesses Dao. (Chapter 77)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 77)
Acts, but is not concerned with the results. (Chapter 77)
Accomplishes his tasks, but does not dwell on them. (Chapter 77)
He does not desire to display his virtue. (Chapter 77)
In the world, nothing is softer and weaker than water. (Chapter 78)
Yet for attacking that which is hard and strong, (Chapter 78)
There is nothing that can surpass it. (Chapter 78)
This is because it endlessly replaces itself. (Chapter 78)
Weakness conquers strength. (Chapter 78)
Softness conquers hardness. (Chapter 78)
In the world, there is no one who does not know this, (Chapter 78)
But there is no one who can practice it. (Chapter 78)
Thus the sage says : (Chapter 78)
Accepting upon oneself the disgrace of the nation (Chapter 78)
Is called being master of the shrines. (Chapter 78)
Accepting upon oneself the misfortune of the nation (Chapter 78)
Is called being king of the world. (Chapter 78)
Honest words seem contrary. (Chapter 78)
Harmonize a great resentment, (Chapter 79)
And there must exist some remaining resentment. (Chapter 79)
How can this be considered good? (Chapter 79)
Thus the sage : (Chapter 79)
Holds the left side of an agreement, (Chapter 79)
But does not demand payment of people. (Chapter 79)
Therefore : to have De is to take charge of youragreements; (Chapter 79)
To be without De is to take charge of taking away fromothers. (Chapter 79)
The Way of heaven, while without favor, (Chapter 79)
Is always with virtuous people. (Chapter 79)
In a small nation with few citizens : (Chapter 80)
Ensure that it has the weapons of ten nobles, but does notuse them. (Chapter 80)
Ensure that the citizens take death seriously, and do notmigrate far. (Chapter 80)
Even though they have boats and carriages, there is noplace to take advantage of them. (Chapter 80)
Even though they have armor and weapons, there is noplace to display them. (Chapter 80)
Ensure that the citizens return to knotting ropes and usingthem, (Chapter 80)
Find deliciousness in their food, (Chapter 80)
Beauty in their clothes, (Chapter 80)
Contentment in their dwellings, (Chapter 80)
Happiness in their customs. (Chapter 80)
Although neighboring nations overlook one another, (Chapter 80)
And sounds of roosters and dogs can be heard in oneanother – (Chapter 80)
The citizens reach old age and die, (Chapter 80)
And do not come and go between one another. (Chapter 80)
True words are not beautiful; (Chapter 81)
Beautiful words are not true. (Chapter 81)
He who has virtue does not argue; (Chapter 81)
He who argues does not have virtue. (Chapter 81)
He who knows is not learned; (Chapter 81)
He who is learned does not know. (Chapter 81)
The sage does not accumulate things – (Chapter 81)
Since through serving people, the more one has; (Chapter 81)
Since through giving to people, one has even more. (Chapter 81)
The Way of heaven benefits and does not cause harm. (Chapter 81)
The Way of the sage acts yet does not strive. (Chapter 81)
